    Discovery of Pyrrole-imidazole Polyamides as PD-L1 Expression Inhibitors and Their Anticancer Activity via Immune and Nonimmune Pathways

    • Ming Wang

    SUBJECTS:
    • Amides,
    • Cancer,

    • Organic polymers,
    • Cells
    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    In recent years, PD-1 immune checkpoint inhibitors based on monoclonal antibodies have revolutionized cancer therapy, but there still exist unresolved issues, such as the high cost, the relatively low response rates, and so on, compared with small-molecule drugs. Herein a type of pyrrole-imidazole (Py-Im) polyamide as a small-molecule DNA binder was designed and synthesized, which could competitively bind to the same double-stranded DNA stretch in the PD-L1 promoter region as the STAT3 binding site and thus downregulate PD-L1 expression. It was demonstrated that the Py-Im polyamides directly caused apoptosis in tumor cells and retarded cell migration in the absence of T cells through inhibiting the Akt/caspase-3 pathway. Also, in a coculture system, they enhanced the T-cell-mediated killing of tumor cells by the reversal of immune escape. Because such polyamides induced antitumor effects via both immune and nonimmune pathways, they could be further developed as promising PD-L1 gene-targeting antitumor drugs.

    Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Tumor immunotherapy refers to therapeutic strategies aimed at regulating the immune system to eradicate cancer.(1) Tumors suppress the effector functions of T lymphocytes by modulating the inhibitory pathways, called immune checkpoints.(2) Programmed death-1 (PD-1 or CD279) and its ligand PD-L1 (also termed B7-H1 or CD274), which are members of the B7 family of molecules, constitute the most promising immune checkpoint in cancer immunotherapy. The engagement of PD-1 with PD-L1 delivers a coinhibitory signal in T cells and regulates the production of cytokines such as interferons (IFNs).(3,4) The blockade of the PD-1/PD-L1 interaction therefore rejuvenates T cells and increases antitumor immunity. Antihuman PD-L1 monoclonal antibodies (mAbs), such as avelumab (Merck & Co.), atezolizumab (F. Hoffmann-La Roche), and durvalumab (Astrazeneca), are used for cancer treatments for non-small-cell lung cancer, urothelial carcinoma, and metastatic Merkel cell carcinoma. The mAbs specific for the PD-1 immune checkpoint are effective in some cancer patients in terms of progression-free survival, overall survival, and tolerability, but the high cost of these agents may affect the economic sustainability of the healthcare system, there exists immunogenic side effects, and some patients fail to respond to the treatment with such drugs based on clinical follow-up data. It is thus imperative to develop small-molecule modulators for the PD-1 immune checkpoint.(5) Meanwhile, more recent studies have shown that PD-L1 delivers an important intrinsic signal into tumors, which could enhance the cell proliferation and survival by inhibiting autophagy and mTOR activation in the absence of PD-1, but extensive studies have not been conducted so far.(6,7)
    On the other hand, signal transducer and activator of transcription (STAT) plays a key role in signal transduction and transcriptional activation. The STAT family consists of six members, STAT1âSTAT6, of which the gene encoding STAT3 is located on chromosome 17 q21.2.(8,9) STAT3 is an important member of the signaling and transcriptional activator family and is broadly expressed in many different types of tissues and cells.(10) When STAT3 is overactivated, it exhibits an oncogenic property and plays roles in the proliferation, differentiation, invasion, metastasis, antiapoptosis, and angiogenesis in tumor cells.(8,11) It was also demonstrated that the continual activation of STAT3 in tumor cells is associated with the abnormal expression of PD-L1 protein.(12,13) The current studies have shown that STAT3 interacts with the promoter region of PD-L1 and regulates its expression,(14â17) which provides a feasible site for Py-Im polyamides target-regulating the PD-L1 expression.
    Studies on netropsin and distamycin, both of which are known as natural products, suggested that a certain class of small-molecule compounds can specifically recognize predetermined DNA sequences and interact with the minor groove of double-stranded DNA molecules.(18,19) Inspired by these two small-molecule compounds, Dervan and colleagues at the California Institute of Technology first developed pyrrole-imidazole (Py-Im) polyamides similar to the two natural small-molecule compounds.(20) This type of small-molecule compound, which mainly comprises N-methylpyrrole (Py), N-methylimidazole (Im) and aliphatic chain amino acid residues, can recognize and interact with DNA base pairs in the DNA minor groove with sequence specificity and has good cell membrane permeability.(21,22) In addition, Dervanâs group revealed the rules of the recognition by Py-Im polyamides targeting the DNA sequences, that is, a Py/Py pair nonpreferentially binding to TÂ·A and AÂ·T, a Py/Im pair specifying CÂ·G, and an Im/Py pair for GÂ·C.(23â26) Next, Zhang et al. reported that an (S)-Î²-hydroxy-Î³-aminobutyric acid/Î²-alanine pair can discriminate TÂ·A from AÂ·T.(27,28) To date, all four WatsonâCrick base pairs, CÂ·G, GÂ·C, TÂ·A, and AÂ·T, in the DNA minor groove can be specifically recognized by the different recognition units based on the rules of recognition in the interaction between polyamides and DNA. On the basis of the affinity and specificity of this kind of molecule for B-DNA, Dervanâs group reported the effect of polyamides on the expression of the corresponding genes.(21,22,26,29) Then, Fukuda and colleagues demonstrated that Py-Im polyamides could specifically interact with the TGF-Î²1 promoter and effectively alleviate a progressive kidney disease.(30) More recently, Fukuda and Sugiyama, in collaboration with a Japanese pharmaceutical company, demonstrated that polyamide-targeted TGF-Î²1 gene therapy was effective in wound scar repair and predicted that the polyamide could be developed as a gene-targeted drug for clinical treatment.(31,32)
    In this work, we newly developed three Py-Im polyamides, of which two specifically interacted with the sequence of the target PD-L1 promoter and one was mismatched to the target according to the âpolyamide/DNA recognition ruleâ. We then examined the ability and influence of their binding to the PD-L1 target gene sequence by monitoring the downstream gene expression and examined the mechanism by which the synthetic compounds modulated cancer cell apoptosis. Experimental results have shown that our synthetic matched Py-Im polyamides are able to downregulate the inducible PD-L1 expression by competitively inhibiting the STAT3 binding to PD-L1 promoter region, resulting in the poptosis of cancer cells not only by the nonimmune pathway, that is, Akt/caspase-3, but also by the immune pathway. This works sheds light on cost-effective cancer immunotherapy based on downregulating the expression of PD-L1 that reduces the PD-1 coinhibitory signaling and rejuvenates the T cells for effectively killing tumor cells.

    Results

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Py-Im Polyamides Competitively Interact with the STAT3 Binding Site in the Promoter Region of the PD-L1 Gene at the Extracellular Level

    Design and Target Binding of Novel Polyamides to a PD-L1 Gene DNA Sequence

    The structures of newly designed Py-Im polyamides 1â3 are depicted (Figure 1A), and their synthetic strategy and characterization are shown (Scheme S1, Experimental Section). The DNA sequences of the STAT3 binding site (SBS) in the PD-L1 promoter region are shown (Figure 1B and Table 1). The polyamides examined in this study include two matched Py-Im polyamides 1 and 2 and a mismatched Py-Im polyamide (Mis-polyamide) to the PD-L1 28nt wild-type double-stranded DNA sequence (wt-ds-DNA, Table 1). Polyamides 1 and 2 can specifically recognize and bind to matched ds-DNA and Mis-polyamide cannot, according to âpolyamide/DNA recognition ruleâ.(23â28) The possible binding modes of the Py-Im polyamides to the target DNA based on the âpolyamide/DNA recognition ruleâ are illustrated (Figure 1B).
    Table 1. Sequences of DNA Oligomers Used in This Study
    oligomerssequences
    PD-L1Â 28nt-wt-ds-DNAÂ (wt-ds-DNA)5â²-TTCCGCCGATTTCACCGAAGGTCAGGAA-3â²
    3â²-AAGGCGGCTAAAGTGGCTTCCAGTCCTT-5â²
    PD-L1Â 28nt-wt-ss-DNAÂ (ss-DNA)5â²-TTCCGCCGATTTCACCGAAGGTCAGGAA-3â²
    PD-L1Â 28nt-mut-ds-DNAÂ (mut-ds-DNA)5â²-TTCCGCCGATTGCGCTGGAGGTCAGGAA-3â²
    3â²-AAGGCGGCTAACGCGACCTCCAGTCCTT-5â²
    5â²-biotinâds-DNA5â²-biotinâTTCCGCCGATTTCACCGAAGGTCAGGAA-TATA-TTCCTGACCTTCGGTGAAATCGGCGGAA-3â²

    Analysis of the Interaction between Py-Im Polyamides and Target DNAs by the Electrophoretic Mobility Shift Assay (EMSA)

    We first examined whether the newly designed polyamides interact with SBS in the PD-L1 promoter at physiologically relevant concentrations (Figure 2A). The interaction between polyamides 1 and 2 and their matched DNA sequence (wt-ds-DNA, Table 1) became more and more strong in the compound concentration-dependent mode (<8 Î¼M) because a type of polyamide/ds-DNA complex was formed (red dashed arrow). At a concentration of 1 Î¼M, such interaction was weak; when the concentration was 2 Î¼M, it was more explicit. When the polyamide concentration reached 16 Î¼M, the intensity of the wt-ds-DNA band and the polyamide/wt-ds-DNA complex band was markedly reduced. This phenomenon is called Beerâs law, in which the agglutination viscosity of the compound may damage the DNA when the concentration is too high.(33) By contrast, no significant binding was observed between the Py-Im polyamides and the single-stranded DNA (ss-DNA) and between the Mis-polyamide and the SBS of the PD-L1 promoter.
    We next performed a competitive EMSA in the presence of the STAT3 protein to examine the binding ability of 1 and 2 to SBS (5â²-TTCACCGAA-3â²/5â²-TTCGGTGAA-3â², Figure 1B) in the promoter of PD-L1. When the STAT3 protein interacted with the 28nt double-stranded DNA (wt-ds-DNA, Table 1) in the PD-L1 promoter, two lagging bands were observed in lanes 4â7 and 10 and 11 (Figure 2B), which was possibly due to two structurally different wt-ds-DNA/protein complexes. With the increase in Py-Im polyamides, the bands of wt-ds-DNA/protein complexes decreased, and those of wt-ds-DNA/polyamide complexes increased in a polyamide concentration-dependent manner, and the band of wt-ds-DNA/protein complexes apparently disappeared at a compound concentration of â¥8 Î¼M. In contrast, as seen in lanes 15 and 16, the Mis-polyamide did not influence the binding of the STAT3 protein to the SBS. The results indicate that newly designed polyamides can strongly interact with the SBS to inhibit the interaction between the STAT3 protein and the target, strongly suggesting that polyamides might possess an ability to modulate the expression of PD-L1.

    Analysis of Tm Values for PD-L1 Double-Stranded DNAs in the Presence/Absence of Py-Im Polyamides

    To examine the thermal stability of the complex formed between the polyamides and target DNAs, the temperature (Tm/Â°C), at which half of the DNA was melted, was calculated by monitoring the ultraviolet (UV) absorbance at 260 nm (Figure S1).(34) Upon the interaction of polyamides 1 or 2 with the matched wt-ds-DNA of the PD-L1 promoter, an increase in the melting temperature of the wt-ds-DNA was observed (Table 2, Figure S1A,B). When the ratio of Py-Im polyamide 1 or 2 to the DNA concentration was 1:1, the melting temperature of 1 and 2 was increased by 8.2 and 7.0 Â°C, respectively, whereas there was almost no change in the case of the Mis-polyamide (Figure S1C). When the ratio of polyamide to DNA concentration was >1, however, the melting temperature almost no longer changed, suggesting that the DNA was saturated with Py-Im polyamides when the ratio of polyamide to DNA concentration was 1. When Py-Im polyamide 1 was compared with 2, the former was more effective in binding to DNA in a cell-free system, possibly because there were more hydrogen bonds between the longer Py-Im polyamide 1 and the DNA. The Mis-polyamide had no effect on the Tm of the wt-ds-DNA, indicating that the newly synthesized Py-Im polyamides 1 and 2 were highly specific and possessed strong affinity to the matched wt-ds-DNA. By contrast, no thermal shift was observed when mixing polyamides 1/2 and a mutant ds-DNA (mut-ds-DNA, Table 2) (Figure S1D,E).
    Table 2. Tm (Â°C) Values for the Interaction between Py-Im Polyamides and ds-DNAa
    Â Â wt-ds-DNAmut-ds-DNA
    ds-DNA/polyamidepolyamideÂ 1polyamideÂ 2Mis-polyamidepolyamideÂ 1polyamideÂ 2
    Tm/Â°C1:070.0Â Â±Â 0.170.0Â Â±Â 0.170.0Â Â±Â 0.173.4Â Â±Â 0.173.4Â Â±Â 0.1
    ÎTm/Â°C1:0.52.7Â Â±Â 0.12.9Â Â±Â 0.10.2Â Â±Â 0.10.2Â Â±Â 0.10.1Â Â±Â 0.1
    ÎTm/Â°C1:18.2Â Â±Â 0.27.0Â Â±Â 0.20.4Â Â±Â 0.10.3Â Â±Â 0.10.2Â Â±Â 0.1
    ÎTm/Â°C1:48.6Â Â±Â 0.37.3Â Â±Â 0.20.7Â Â±Â 0.10.6Â Â±Â 0.20.4Â Â±Â 0.2
    a

    Values are expressed as mean Â± SD (triplicates).

    Understanding the Mechanism Underlying the Interaction between Polyamides and the Target DNAs by Circular Dichroism and Surface Plasmon Resonance

    To further analyze the binding properties of the novel polyamides to the target DNA sequences in the PD-L1 gene promoter region, including the affinity, specificity, and stoichiometry, circular dichroism (CD) and surface plasmon resonance (SPR) techniques were applied to examine the interaction properties of polyamides 1â3 with target DNAs (wt-ds-DNA, mut-ds-DNA, ss-DNA, and 5â²-biotinâds-DNA in Table 1). CD and SPR techniques are, more importantly, regarded as practical methods for illuminating the interaction of small molecules with DNAs. In particular, CD spectroscopy has been extensively used for exploring the nature of structural changes of nuclei acids in the presence of binders.(35â38)
    CD spectra of the wt-ds-DNA alone (dotted line) showed a palpable positive band at 283.5 to 284.0 nm and a weak negative band at 244.5â145.0 nm (Figure 3A,B), corresponding to a double-stranded DNA,(39) whereas those of the three compounds alone were invisible due to their nonoptically active properties (dashed line). It was observed that the intensity of positive peaks at 283.5â287.5 nm presented an obvious change with a red shift of 3.0â3.5 nm and a drop of 1.0 to 1.1 in the ellipticity, and that of the negative band at 244.5â145.0 nm did slightly change but in the opposite direction, with the gradual titration of polyamide 1 or 2 into the wt-ds-DNA-containing solution at 2:1, 0.4:1, 0.6:1, 0.8:1, 1.0:1, and 2.0:1 ratios of compound/DNA. It is worth noting that there exists two different isoelliptic points at 340.0 nm (Figure 3A) and 325.0 nm (Figure 3B), which indicate the two-state nature of the structural transition upon polyamide binding to wt-ds-DNA. More importantly, we found two types of slightly different strong induced CD (ICD) spectra of the polyamides from 300.0 to 394.0 nm with a wavelength of 340.0 nm in maximum ellipticity (Figure 3A) and from 297.5 to 374.5 nm with a wavelength of 325.0 nm in maximum ellipticity (Figure 3B), both suggesting that there is a strong interaction between 1 or 2 and the target wt-ds-DNA. In addition, the CD signals at 340.0 nm plotted against the compound/DNA ratio showed an approximately 1:1 polyamide 1âDNA complex, with the mode of interaction being a polyamide 1 binding to a wt-ds-DNA in the minor groove according to the previously discovered âpolyamide/DNA recognition ruleâ, as shown in the inset of Figure 3A. Likewise, the inset in Figure 3B also demonstrated the stoichiometry of a 1:1 polyamide 2âDNA complex. As shown in Figure S2A, a negative-control Mut-polyamide (Figure 1), which was expected not to recognize and interact with the 28nt wt-ds-DNA in the PD-L1 gene promoter sequence in the minor groove on the basis of the âpolyamide/DNA recognition ruleâ, had no influence on the target wt-ds-DNA under the same experimental conditions, even when a higher concentration of Mut-polyamide at 8 Î¼M was used.
    To examine the ability of 1 and 2 to selectively recognize and bind to matched ds-DNA (wt-ds-DNA, Table 1) versus mutant ds-DNA (mut-ds-DNA, Table 1) based on the âpolyamide/DNA recognition ruleâ and single-stranded DNA (ss-DNA, Table 1), the CD spectra of the 28nt mut-ds-DNA and ss-DNA were measured in the presence and absence of 1 and 2. 1 and 2 had almost no influence on the CD behaviors of mut-ds-DNA and ss-DNA, but the CD spectra of the mut-ds-DNA and ss-DNA alone were both characteristic of double- and single-stranded DNA structures, respectively (Figure S2BâE). The CD spectra of the mut-ds-DNA displayed almost an identically strong peak and trough at 283.0 to 283.5 nm and 244.0 to 245.5 nm (Figure S2B,C), respectively, whereas those of ss-DNA had a strong peak at 282.0 nm and a relatively weak trough at 241.0 nm (Figure S2D,E). All in all, the CD results demonstrate that the examined polyamides 1 and 2 can specifically recognize and strongly bind to 28nt matched ds-DNA in the PD-L1 gene promoter region with a 1:1 stoichiometry of polyamide/ds-DNA.
    SPR is a convenient and effective method for screening new drugs, especially for evaluating the binding natures of small molecules with target DNAs.(27,28,38,40) In this study, the binding ability/affinity of the polyamides to the target ds-DNA sequence (5â²-biotinâds-DNA, Table 1) was evaluated on the same sensor chip with the same immobilized 5â²-biotinâds-DNA (Figure 3C,D and Table 3). The KD of polyamide 1 binding to ds-DNA was 8.28 (Â±0.56) Ã 10â9 M, whose interaction was approximately six times stronger than that of polyamide 2 with a KD of 4.99 (Â±0.47) Ã 10â8 M. Both of the experimental SPR sensorgrams (curves in color) were very well fitted to a 1:1 global theoretical fitting model with mass transport (curves in black). Furthermore, binding of the polyamides 1 (Figure 3C) and 2 (Figure 3D) to the target DNA sequence led to saturation at relatively higher compound concentrations of 350 to 500 nM, implying a 1:1 stoichiometry of 1 or 2 to the target DNA. It is worth noting that polyamide 2 interacted swiftly with the target DNA to achieve a steady state at a concentration of 20 nM, whereas polyamide 1 attained a steady state at concentrations of not less than 80 nM, demonstrating that there was a more than five-fold difference in the binding rates of polyamide 1 with a ka of 6.47 (Â±0.18) Ã 106 Mâ1 sâ1 and 2 with a ka of 1.28 (Â±0.14) Ã 106 Mâ1 sâ1. But interestingly, polyamide 1 was much more slowly dissociated from the sensor chip with a kd of 1.06 (Â±0.23) Ã 10â2 sâ1 than 2 with a kd of 32.3 (Â±0.4) Ã 10â2 sâ1. In combination with the experimental results by EMSA and Tm analyses and our previous studies on polyamides, the rationale for the above extracellular results is possibly that the long polyamide 1 more slowly specifically recognized and bound to a long DNA sequence with nine base pairs (5â²-TTCACCGAA-3â²/5â²-TTCGGTGAA-3â², Figure 1A) and was more slowly dissociated from it than the short polyamide 2 that interacted with a short DNA sequence with six base pairs (5â²-CACCGA-3â²/5â²-TCGGTG-3â², Figure 1B) and was dissociated from it. By contrast, almost no interaction between Mis-polyamide (Figure 1) and wt-ds-DNA was observed at lower concentrations. Although nonspecific binding was noted at higher concentrations, the mode of interaction and the precise parameters for the binding of Mis-polyamide to wt-ds-DNA could not be obtained, as shown in Figure S3. Likewise, we could not obtain interaction kinetic parameters between three polyamides and ss-DNAs (forward oligo of ds-DNA and reverse oligo of ds-DNA), as almost no binding of all three polyamides (Figure 1) to ss-DNA was observed at experimental concentrations of 10â1000 nM. The experimental results are roughly consistent with those obtained in EMSA (Figure 2), Tm value analysis (Table 2), and CD (Figure 3A,B).
    Table 3. Binding Kinetic Constants of Py-Im Polyamides 1 and 2 to 5â²-Biotinâds-DNA (Table 1) by SPRa
    DNAka (Mâ1 sâ1)kd (sâ1)KD (M)
    polyamideÂ 11.28Â (Â±0.14)bÂ ÃÂ 1061.06Â (Â±0.23)Â ÃÂ 10â28.28Â (Â±0.56)Â ÃÂ 10â9
    polyamideÂ 26.47Â (Â±0.18)Â ÃÂ 10632.3Â (Â±0.4)Â ÃÂ 10â24.99Â (Â±0.47)Â ÃÂ 10â8
    a

    ka, association rate constant (Mâ1 sâ1); kd, dissociation rate constant (sâ1); KD, dissociation equilibrium constant (M); KD = kd/ka.

    b

    Standard deviation is given in parentheses.

    Taken together, the present results demonstrated that polyamides 1 and 2 exhibited high affinity to matched wt-ds-DNA at a polyamide/wt-ds-DNA ratio of 1:1, especially polyamide 1. It is of note that a 2:1 binding motif of polyamides 1/2 to the ds-DNA was not observed unless exposed to high concentrations of DNA.

    Docking Study on the Interaction of Py-Im Polyamides 1 and 2 with the Target DNA Sequence

    Next, we further examined the mode and affinity of the interaction between Py-Im polyamides and the target ds-DNA, 5â²-TTCACCGAA-3â²/5â²-TTCGGTGAA-3â² by using an in silico calculation based on the energy-minimized structures of the complex.(27,41,38,42) The matched hairpin polyamide appeared to tightly interact with the DNA minor groove of the target ds-DNA in an antiparallel manner, as shown in Figure 3E. We then calculated the binding energy and LibDock score after the polyamides docked with the DNA sequence (Figure 3F). The in silico results coincided well with the previous experimental data, in which the calculated binding energy and the LibDock score of the Py-Im polyamide 1/DNA complex were â680.61395 kcal/mol and 706.467, whereas those of the Py-Im polyamide 2/DNA were â541.15002 kcal/mol and 505.427. In contrast, Mis-polyamide cannot strongly interact with the target ds-DNA in the DNA minor groove based on the docking results of the binding energy and the LibDock score (Figure S4). The in silico calculation also suggested that there existed a strong interaction between polyamides 1 and 2 and their target DNA sequence, and the number of hydrogen bonds dominantly affected the polyamide affinity to the specific sequence of the DNA in the cell-free in vitro system.
    In summary, the extracellular results demonstrated that the matched polyamides 1 and 2 strongly interacted with the STAT3 protein binding site in the promoter region of PD-L1 and could competitively inhibit the binding of the STAT3 protein to the DNA motif. Furthermore, at the extracellular level, polyamide 1 exhibits relatively stronger binding ability than 2 in the cell-free in vitro system.

    Py-Im Polyamides Suppress PD-L1 Expression in Tumor Cells

    In general, Py-Im polyamides not only show high specificity to certain DNA sequences but also have high cell permeability; that is, they can penetrate the cell membrane into the nucleus. Thus they may specifically regulate the expression of target genes through binding to the promoter of the genes. It was reported that IFN-Î³ could induce PD-L1 expression at a high level in HCC827 and MDA-MB-231 cells.(43,44) Thus we first examined the effect of the newly synthesized Py-Im polyamides on the PD-L1 mRNA expression in the presence of IFN-Î³ in both cancer cells. Both Py-Im polyamides 1 and 2 concentration-dependently inhibited the PD-L1 mRNA expression in the two tumor cell lines, in which the inhibitory effect of the Py-Im polyamide 2 was more pronounced (Figure 4A,B). Similarly, the PD-L1 protein expression was efficiently suppressed by the addition of 1 or 2 in a concentration-dependent manner, with polyamide 2 being more effective, as depicted (Figure 4C,D). By contrast, Mis-polyamide, which failed to recognize 5â²-TTCACCGAA-3â²/5â²-TTCGGTGAA-3â² (Figure 1 and Table 1), showed essentially no effects on the expression of PD-L1 protein, consistent with the results of the cell-free in vitro system (Figure 2, Figures S1C, S2A, and S3, and Table 2). Noticeably, polyamide 2 inhibited the PD-L1 expression at both the mRNA and protein levels more efficiently than 1 in tumor cells, whereas polyamide 1 interacted with the SBS of the PD-L1 promoter more potently than 2 in cell-free in vitro systems. This is possibly because polyamide 2 is shorter than 1. It was reported that the cell permeability of polyamides was influenced by their size, and the shorter polyamides generally had higher cell permeability than the longer ones.(45)
    In addition, we demonstrated that polyamide 2 could permeate into the MDA-MB-231 cell nucleus to interact with target DNA like a nucleic acid dye, Hoechst 33342, by the nucleus location experiment (Figure S5).
    Collectively, the newly synthesized Py-Im polyamides 1 and 2 can inhibit the expression of PD-L1 gene in tumor cells at both transcriptional and translational levels.

    Py-Im Polyamides Promote T-Cell-Mediated Tumor Cell Killing and IL-2 Production

    To examine the ability of the newly synthesized polyamides to kill tumor cells in the presence of T cells, we carried out assays on IL-2 secretion levels and T-cell-mediated tumor killing in coculture systems of tumor cells with Jurkat T cells. Several lines of evidence have shown that binding of PD-L1 expressed on tumor cells to PD-1 expressed on T cells reduces the T-cell activation and IL-2 production.(46â48) For example, the coculture of melanoma cells expressing PD-L1 by IFN-Î³ with Jurkat T cells results in the impaired production of IL-2 in T cells.(46) In addition, the coculture of breast cancer cells, lung cancer cells, and the like with Jurkat T cells has the same phenomenon.(49,50) Because the newly synthesized Py-Im polyamides quite reduced the PD-L1 expression in the two tumor cells, as previously described (Figure 4), we further explored whether the down-regulation of PD-L1 could influence the immune responses in the coculture system of T cells (Jurkat cells) and tumor cells, like HCC827 and MDA-MB-231 (Figure 5A,B). The amounts of IL-2, which was secreted from T cells into the culture supernatants in response to HCC827 cells treated with the Py-Im polyamides 1 and 2, were increased by 28.20 (31.41%) and 51.17 pg/mL (57.00%), respectively, compared with those without compounds (Figure 5A). Similarly, the amounts in response to MDA-MB-231 were increased by 48.06 (33.00%) and 87.89 pg/mL (60.35%), respectively (Figure 5B). The results demonstrated that addition of both polyamides 1 and 2 can promote the secretion of IL-2 in such a coculture system and that polyamide 2 was more effective in stimulating IL-2 secretion than 1 but less effective than a PD-1/PD-L1 inhibitor 2 (BMS202, Figure S6) as a positive control, which enhanced the secretion of IL-2 by almost 100% from T cells in response to both tumor cells treated with the compound, whereas Mis-polyamide almost failed to enhance the secretion of IL-2 in both culture systems.
    Next, we analyzed the effect of the Py-Im polyamides 1 and 2 on T-cell-mediated cytotoxicity against tumor cells. Tumor cell lines HCC827 and MDA-MB-231 were treated with 1 or 2 and challenged by T cells. Then, the viability of the tumor cells was determined by the standard CCK-8 assay. When HCC827 cells treated with 1 and 2 were incubated with T cells, 48.00 and 70.00% of tumor cells underwent apoptosis, respectively, relative to a control without any drug, and the decrease in the cell viability for HCC827 cells treated with BMS202 as a positive control was close to 70.87%. Similarly, 50.73 and 82.11% of 1- and 2-treated MDA-MB-231 cells were killed in the presence of T cells, respectively, relative to a control without any drugs, and both percentages were lower than that (87.58%) of BMS202-treated MDA-MB-231 cells. Again, polyamide 2 was more effective in the promotion of T-cell killing than 1, but both polyamides were less effective than BMS202. Likewise, we investigated the influence of the studied polyamides on the cell viability of Jurkat cells alone, but almost no cytotoxicity was observed (Figure S7). In addition, the Mis-polyamide had no effect on tested cells.
    Taken together, Py-Im polyamides 1 and 2 could modulate the PD-1 immune checkpoints and promote the secretion of IL-2, leading to the death of tumor cells.

    Py-Im Polyamides Induce Tumor Cell Proliferation Inhibition/Cytotoxicity via Another AKT/Caspapse-3 Pathway and Inhibit Cell Migration

    In the above-used coculture systems, the Py-Im polyamides 1 and 2 possessed a killing effect on tumor cells via T cells. Subsequently, we explored whether both 1 and 2 could exhibit direct cytotoxicity against cancer cells via downregulating the PD-L1 expression in the absence of T cells. Direct toxic effects of the compounds on HCC827 and MDA-MB-231 cells were examined using the standard CCK-8 assay. The cytotoxicity of 1 and 2 against tumor cells increased with the increase in compound concentration, whereas the Mis-polyamide had almost no effect on the direct toxicity (Figure 6A,B). It is noteworthy that the matched and mismatched Py-Im polyamides were essentially nontoxic to normal MRC-5 cells, even at the highest concentration of 32 Î¼M (Figure 6C). The IC50 values of polyamide 2 were 11.84 and 9.05 Î¼M for HCC827 and MDA-MB-231 cells (Table 4), respectively, which were more than two times lower than those of 1, suggesting that polyamide 2 possessed stronger anticancer activity than 1. This result is in accord with the influence of both polyamides 1 and 2 on PD-L1 expression in cancer cells on the whole (Figure 4).
    Table 4. IC50 (Î¼M) of Py-Im Polyamides for HCC827 and MDA-MB-231 Cells
    cell linespolyamideÂ 1polyamideÂ 2Mis-polyamidecisalpine
    HCC82723.23Â Â±Â 0.9811.84Â Â±Â 0.53â«2008.41Â Â±Â 0.48
    MDA-MB-23121.66Â Â±Â 0.879.05Â Â±Â 0.48>2007.92Â Â±Â 0.52
    More importantly, by comparing the results in Figure 6A,B with those obtained in Figure 5C,D, it was found that polyamides 1 and 2 at a concentration of 8 Î¼M could increase the proliferation inhibition/apoptosis of HCC827 cells by 23.40 and 26.14%, respectively, and those of MDA-MB-231 cells by 27.76 and 30.84%, respectively, in the presence of Jurkat T cells, which was attributed to the immune antitumor effect. This suggests that the proliferation inhibition/apoptosis of cancer cells by 1 and 2 was achieved by both a nonimmunosuppressive pathway and an immunosuppressive pathway.
    Then, the effect of 1 and 2 on the migration of HCC827 and MDA-MB-231 cells was examined through a wound healing assay (Figure 6D and Figure S8). The tumor cell migration was inhibited in a polyamide concentration-dependent manner. A 50% inhibition rate was observed at 0.5 to 1.0 Î¼M, and a 70% or greater inhibition rate was observed at a concentration of 2 Î¼M. In particular, polyamide 2 showed an inhibition rate of 86.33% at 2 Î¼M in MDA-MB-231 cells.
    It was reported that PD-L1 itself could modulate the proliferation of tumor cells in the absence of PD-1, which is related to the Akt/m-TOR pathway and autophagy.(6,7) In addition, caspase-3 protein is closely linked to apoptosis and participates in its regulation.(51) On the basis of such previous important results and analysis, we attempted to elucidate the mechanism by which the Py-Im polyamides could induce tumor cell apoptosis or inhibit proliferation by downregulating the expression of PD-L1 gene independently of the immune signaling. In our study, polyamide 2 was applied because it appeared to interact with the target DNA sequence more efficiently than 1. Polyamide 2 significantly inhibited the expression of caspase-3 (pro-caspase-3) and the phosphorylation of Akt (P-Akt), which were closely associated with the expression of PD-L1 protein in cancer cells (Figure 6E,F).(6,7) In contrast, the Mis-polyamide showed no explicit effects on the signaling.
    Collectively, these results demonstrated that the Py-Im polyamides inhibited the growth of tumor cells by suppressing the Akt/caspase-3 signaling as a new pathway independently of the modulation of PD-1 immune checkpoints.

    Discussion and Conclusions

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    PD-L1 belongs to the B7 family of transmembrane proteins and negatively modulates the function of T cells, thereby attenuating the cytotoxicity of T cells against tumor cells and ultimately mediating tumor immune escape.(52) PD-L1 is highly expressed in various tumor cells and thus is a target for the early diagnosis and immunotherapy of cancer.(53â56) In this study, we demonstrated that the newly synthesized Py-Im polyamides predominately bound to the SBS of the PD-L1 promoter, thereby inhibiting the PD-L1 expression at the transcriptional and translational levels. In the coculture system, the Py-Im polyamides were capable of enhancing T-cell-mediated tumor killing and IL-2 production (Figure 5). In the tumor microenvironment, tumor cells show adaptive immune resistance by upregulating the PD-L1 expression inducible by IFN-Î³.(57) It was previously reported that the PD-1/PD-L1 interaction inhibited the secretion of IL-2 and IFN-Î³.(54,55) We thus hypothesized that the downregulation of the PD-L1 gene expression by the Py-Im polyamides attenuated the interaction between PD-1 and PD-L1, promoted the recovery of T-cell functions, and consequently elicited antitumor effects. Further direct evidence should, however, be required for the clearer elucidation of the PD-L1/PD-1 immune-mediated apoptosis mechanism by polyamides.
    It is intriguing that the Py-Im polyamides 1 and 2 exhibited a direct toxic effect on both tumor cells and inhibited cell proliferation (Figure 6A,B) in the absence T cells. This finding prompted us to examine whether there exists another pathway to cause cancer cell apoptosis, as recent studies have shown that PD-L1 exerted intrinsic effects on tumors, in which PD-L1 could enhance the cell proliferation and survival by inhibiting autophagy and mTOR activation in the absence of PD-1.
    We thus examined the dynamics of p-Akt- (Ser473) and caspase-3-related proteins. Both Py-Im polyamides 1 and 2 could significantly inhibit the phosphorylation of Akt (Ser473) and reduce the expression of caspase-3, resulting in apoptosis. This implies that the Py-Im polyamides 1 and 2 inhibit the proliferation of cancer cells and promote apoptosis in the absence of T cells, possibly through the AKT signaling/caspase-3 pathway. But further studies should be required to clarify the mechanism by which the newly synthesized Py-Im polyamides enhance antitumor effects.(6,7)
    It has been shown that STAT3 could regulate the transcription of PD-L1 by directly binding to its promoter.(14,15) The PD-L1 expression is also known to be elevated with an oncogene ALK mutation, whereas the knockdown of STAT3 abrogates the expression.(58) In addition, LMP1 positively regulates PD-L1 expression by promoting the phosphorylation of STAT3. On the contrary, the inhibition of STAT3 phosphorylation by the JAK3 inhibitor CP-690550 suppresses the LMP1-induced PD-L1 expression.(59) Blocking the STAT3 signaling pathway in tumor cells could therefore effectively inhibit the tumor cell proliferation, migration, and angiogenesis and promote apoptosis. To bind to the STAT3-binding site in the PD-L1 promoter, the designed compounds in this study could competitively inhibit the interaction of STAT3 with the DNA sequence. However, an investigation of the effect of the compounds on the phosphorylation of STAT3 and the downstream signaling leading to cell proliferation and migration is required.(60)
    The epithelialâmesenchymal transition (EMT) is a pivotal step in the early stages of tumor metastasis, and it accelerates the malignant transformation of tumors.(61) It was demonstrated that PD-L1 is highly expressed in various malignant tumor tissues such as lung cancer and breast cancer, and its expression level is closely related to the clinical stage and prognosis of patients.(53,62) A high level of PD-L1 expression promotes the EMT in normal skin epithelial cells and accelerates carcinogenesis.(12,63) As shown in Figure 6D, the matched polyamides 1 and 2 significantly inhibited tumor cell migration, which may be related to inhibition of the EMT.(64)
    In summary, our study showed that small-molecule Py-Im polyamides could predominately bind to the SBS in the PD-L1 promoter, resulting in the downregulation of transcription and translation of PD-L1. Consequently, the compounds could regulate the PD-1/PD-L1 immune checkpoints, leading to the augmentation of anticancer effects. More strikingly, such small-molecule polyamides could also have a direct toxic effect on cancer cells, retard tumor cell migration, inhibit the expression of Akt/caspase-3, and promote apoptosis in the absence of T cells. The Py-Im polyamides therefore have the potential to be a prototype of therapeutics as PD-L1 inhibitors. A scheme for the proposed molecular mechanism by which small-molecule Py-Im polyamides specifically downregulate the expression of PD-L1 gene and promote antitumor effects via immune and nonimmune pathways is depicted (Figure 7).

    Experimental Section

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Chemistry

    General

    1H NMR spectra were measured on a Bruker AVANCE III NMR spectrometer, in which chemical shifts (Î´) were recorded in parts per million relative to residual solvent and coupling constants were measured in hertz (spin multiplicity: singlet (s), doublet (d), triplet (t), quartet (q), quintet (qu), multiplet (m), and broad (br)). UV spectra were obtained in HBS-EP buffer using a Shimadzu UV-2550 spectrophotometer. Mass spectra were measured using matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization time-of-flight (MALDI-TOF) mass spectrometry with a BioTOF II apparatus from Bruker Daltonics in a positive ionization mode, except where otherwise stated. High-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) analysis was conducted on a Shimadzu LC-20AT HPLC system equipped with a ChemcoPak, Chemcoband, 5-ODS-H, 150 Ã 10 mm reversed-phase column using 0.1% TFA in water with acetonitrile as an eluent at a flow rate of 1.0 mL/min with a linear gradient elution of 0â100% acetonitrile in 30 min with detection at 254 nm, except where otherwise stated. Preparatory reversed-phase HPLC was conducted using a Shimadzu LC-6AD HPLC system equipped with a YMC-Pack R&D ODS, D-ODS-5-ST, S-5 Î¼m, 150 Ã 20 mm reversed-phase column using 0.1% TFA in water with acetonitrile as an eluent at a flow rate of 3.0 mL/min under appropriate gradient elution conditions for the detection of optical density at 254 or 350 nm. Collected fractions were analyzed by electrospray ionizationâtime-of-flight mass spectrometry (ESI-TOFMass). A Millipore Milli-Q water purification system was used to prepare pure water with a conductivity at 18 MÎ©, and all buffers were filtered through a 0.22 Î¼m membrane and degassed before the SPR assay using a Biocore system.
    Clear resin (0.52 mequiv/g) and N-{(dimethylamino)-1H-1,2,3-triazolo[4,5-b]-pyridino-1-ylmethylene}-N-methylmethanaminium hexafluorophosphate (HATU) were from Peptides International. 4-{[(9H-Fluoren-9-ylmethoxy)carbonyl]amino}-1-methyl-1H-imidazole-2-carboxylic acid (4, FmocPyCOOH, Scheme S1), 4-{[(9H-fluoren-9-ylmethoxy)carbonyl]amino}-1-methyl-1H-pyrrole-2-carboxylic acid (5, FmocImCOOH, Scheme S1), N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF), dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO), piperidine, and pyridine were obtained from Wako, and N-[(9H-fluoren-9-ylmethoxy)carbonyl]-Î²-alanine (6, Fmoc-Î²-Ala-OH, Scheme S1) and 4-[(9H-fluoren-9-ylmethoxy)carbonyl]aminobutanoic acid (7, Fmoc-Î³-Abu-COOH, Scheme S1) were from Novabiochem. N,N-Diisopropylethylamine (DIEA), acetic anhydride, and N,N-dimethyl-1,3-propanediamine were from Sigma-Aldrich. 1-Hydroxybenzotriazole (HOBt), dicyclohexylcarbodiimide (DCC), dichloromethane (DCM), trifluoroacetic acid (TFA), and acetic acid (HOAc) were from Acros Organics. All other materials and reagents were of highest quality and were purchased from standard suppliers.

    Synthesis

    Polyamides were semiautomatically synthesized using a Pioneer peptide synthesizer (Applied Biosystems, USA). A previously established protocol with a computer-assisted operation system was employed to synthesize the compounds on a 0.10 mmol scale (200 mg of clear resin, 0.52 mequiv/g) based on semimanual Fmoc chemistry.(27,28) In brief, all polyamide solid-phase syntheses were performed for each cycle as follows: deblocking with 20% piperidine/DMF for 5 min, activating with 0.5 M HATU/DMF and 1.0 M DIEA/DMF for 2 min, coupling for 60 min, capping with 5% acetic anhydride/5% pyridine/DMF for 5 min for the minimization of side products, and washing with methanol. Coupling was conducted for 90 min in the case of coupling of any monomer to imidazole and coupling of imidazole itself; all other coupling reactions were carried out with single couple cycles. To swell the Fmoc-Î²-Ala-clear-acid resin (200 mg, 0.10 mmol), 3 mL of DMF was added to a 15 mL plastic centrifuge tube containing the resin. After being swollen for 30 min, the resin was loaded onto a reaction column. The synthetic procedure was regulated by a computer-aided program. Before and after solution transfers, all lines were emptied with argon.
    When the synthesis of the peptides was completed on the synthesizer, the resin was washed with methanol/DCM (1/1 v/v) (3 Ã 1 mL) to remove the unreacted reagents and dried under vacuum. Then, the resin was mixed with 5 mL of (dimethylamino)propylamine (Dp), which was incubated with continuous stirring at 55 Â°C overnight. To remove the resin, the reaction mixture was filtrated through a pad of celite, and the residual product was recovered by washing the resin with methanol/DCM (1/1 v/v). After the pH of the filtrate was adjusted to 4 to 5 with 10% TFA/DCM and the solvent was removed under vacuum, â¼0.3 mL of DMF was added to the residue. The polyamide samples were analyzed by analytical HPLC under monitoring at 254 nm and further purified by using preparatory HPLC with detection at 254 or 350 nm using the following eluent and conditions: 0.1% TFA/MeCN, linear gradient 0â100%, 0â20 min. After fractions were examined by 1H NMR and TOF-Mass, the target products were lyophilized to yield the polyamides 1â3 (Scheme S1) as white or light-yellow powders.
    Polyamides 1â3 were obtained in a recovery of at least 8.1% and at most 16.1% by a single HPLC purification.

    Dp-Î²-PyPy-ImPy-Py-Î²-PyPy-Py-Î³-PyPy-Im-Î²-ImIm-Py-PyPy-Ac (1)

    Yield: 8.1% as a light-yellow powder. By analytical HPLC, tR = 9.98 min, purity is â¥98%. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6): Î´ 10.50 (s, 1H, aromatic NH), 10.46 (s, 2H, aromatic NH), 10.42 (s, 1H, aromatic NH), 10.33 (s, 2H, aromatic NH), 10.26 (s, 1H, aromatic NH), 10.08 (s, 2H, aromatic NH), 9.86â9.78 (m, 3H, aromatic NH), 9.73 (s, 2H, aromatic NH), 9.62 (s, 2H, aromatic NH), 8.01â7.87 (m, 3H, aliphatic NH), 7.82â7.75 (m, 2H, aliphatic NH), 7.46 (s, 1H, aromatic CH), 7.43â7.31 (m, 4H, aromatic CH), 7.27â7.23 (m, 2H, aromatic CH), 7.20 (s, 1H, aromatic CH), 7.14â6.98 (m, 4H, aromatic CH), 6.96â6.89 (m, 6H, aromatic CH), 6.83â6.76 (m, 2H, aromatic CH), 6.73â6.67 (m, 4H, aromatic CH), 6.62â6.57 (m, 4H, aromatic CH), 3.98 (s, 3H, NCH3), 3.95 (s, 3H, NCH3), 3.92 (s, 3H, 2 Ã NCH3), 3.88 (s, 3H, NCH3), 3.85 (s, 6H, 2 Ã NCH3), 3.81 (s, 3H, NCH3), 3.77 (s, 6H, 2 Ã NCH3), 3.74 (s, 6H, 2 Ã NCH3), 3.70 (s, 6H, 2 Ã NCH3), 3.65 (s, 6H, 2 Ã NCH3), 3.57â3.50 (m, 4H, 2 Ã NHCH2), 3.44 (m, 2H, NHCH2), 3.36â3.28 (m, 4H, 2 Ã NHCH2), 2.65 (m, 2H, NMe2CH2), 2.34 (t, 3JH,H = 7.2 Hz, 2H, COCH2), 2.28 (t, 3JH,H = 6.8 Hz, 2H, COCH2), 2.22â2.15 (m, 4H, 2 Ã COCH2), 2.04 (s, 6H, N(CH3)2), 1.97 (s, 1H, COCH3), 1.77 (m, 2H, CH2CH2CH2), 1.52 (m, 2H, CH2CH2CH2). TOF-Mass: m/z calcd for C112H131N42O21[M + H]+: 2400.0474; found: 2400.8130 [M + H]+, 2422.8110 [M + Na]+.

    Dp-Î²-PyIm-Py-Î²-PyPy-Î³-Im-Î²-ImIm-PyPy-Ac (2)

    Yield: 13.4% as an ashen powder. By analytical HPLC, tR = 10.94 min, purity is â¥98%. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6): Î´ 10.43 (s, 1H, aromatic NH), 10.37 (s, 1H, aromatic NH), 10.30 (s, 2H, aromatic NH), 10.13 (s, 1H, aromatic NH), 9.97 (s, 2H, aromatic NH), 9.85 (s, 2H, aromatic NH), 9.71 (s, 1H, aromatic NH), 8.26â8.00 (m, 3H, aliphatic NH), 7.85â7.76 (m, 2H, aliphatic NH), 7.61 (s, 1H, aromatic CH), 7.50 (s, 1H, aromatic CH), 7.42 (s, 1H, aromatic CH), 7.30 (s, 1H, aromatic CH), 7.21â6.97 (m, 6H, aromatic CH), 6.89â6.82 (m, 2H, aromatic CH), 6.76â6.63 (m, 4H, aromatic CH), 3.99 (s, 3H, NCH3), 3.94 (s, 3H, NCH3), 3.90 (s, 6H, 2 Ã NCH3), 3.85 (s, 3H, NCH3), 3.80 (s, 6H, 2 Ã NCH3), 3.76 (s, 3H, NCH3), 3.72 (s, 6H, 2 Ã NCH3), 3.60 (m, 2H, NHCH2), 3.54 (m, 2H, NHCH2), 3.48 (m, 2H, NHCH2), 3.39â3.27 (m, 4H, 2 Ã NHCH2), 2.61 (m, 2H, NMe2CH2), 2.42 (d, 3JH,H = 7.4 Hz, 2H, COCH2), 2.31 (t, 3JH,H = 6.8 Hz, 2H, COCH2), 2.20â2.10 (m, 4H, 2 Ã COCH2), 2.02 (s, 6H, N(CH3)2), 1.97 (s, 1H, COCH3), 1.77 (m, 2H, CH2CH2CH2), 1.53 (m, 2H, CH2CH2CH2). TOF-Mass: m/z calcd for C76H95N30O15[M + H]+: 1667.7593; found: 1667.5201 [M + H]+, 1689.4670 [M + Na]+.

    Dp-Î²-Py-ImIm-Î²-PyPy-Î³-Im-Î²-ImPy-PyPy-Ac (3)

    Yield: 16.1% as a light-yellow powder. By analytical HPLC, tR = 11.97 min, purity is â¥98%. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6): Î´ 10.41 (s, 1H, aromatic NH), 10.36 (s, 1H, aromatic NH), 10.28 (s, 1H, aromatic NH), 10.14 (s, 2H, aromatic NH), 9.95 (s, 1H, aromatic NH), 9.85 (s, 2H, aromatic NH), 9.73 (s, 2H, aromatic NH), 8.28â8.03 (m, 3H, aliphatic NH), 7.87â7.74 (m, 2H, aliphatic NH), 7.63 (s, 1H, aromatic CH), 7.53 (s, 1H, aromatic CH), 7.42 (s, 1H, aromatic CH), 7.30 (s, 1H, aromatic CH), 7.23â7.01 (m, 6H, aromatic CH), 6.88â6.82 (m, 2H, aromatic CH), 6.77â6.63 (m, 4H, aromatic CH), 3.98 (s, 3H, NCH3), 3.94 (s, 3H, NCH3), 3.89 (s, 6H, 2 Ã NCH3), 3.84 (s, 3H, NCH3), 3.80 (s, 6H, 2 Ã NCH3), 3.75 (s, 3H, NCH3), 3.70 (s, 6H, 2 Ã NCH3), 3.61 (m, 2H, NHCH2), 3.52 (m, 2H, NHCH2), 3.48 (m, 2H, NHCH2), 3.40â3.25 (m, 4H, 2 Ã NHCH2), 2.59 (m, 2H, NMe2CH2), 2.40 (d, 3JH,H = 7.4 Hz, 2H, COCH2), 2.30 (t, 3JH,H = 6.8 Hz, 2H, COCH2), 2.22â2.11 (m, 4H, 2 Ã COCH2), 2.02 (s, 6H, N(CH3)2), 1.98 (s, 1H, COCH3), 1.76 (m, 2H, CH2CH2CH2), 1.53 (m, 2H, CH2CH2CH2). TOF-Mass: m/z calcd for C76H95N30O15[M + H]+: 1667.7593; found: 1667.6080 [M + H]+, 1689.8750 [M + Na]+.

    In Vitro Pharmacological Assays

    DNA Oligomers, Cell Lines, and Inhibitors

    Oligomers/primers used in this study were obtained from Sangon (Shanghai, China). The DNA preparations were purified using HPLC, and the quality and identity were confirmed by HPLCâCE (capillary electrophoresis) and TOF-Mass, with the purities being â¥95%. A human non-small-cell lung cancer cell line (HCC827), a human breast cancer cell line (MDA-MB-231), a human fetal lung fibroblast cell line (MRC-5), and a human T-cell lymphoma (Jurkat) were obtained from the Cell Bank, Shanghai Institutes for Biological Sciences, Chinese Academy of Sciences, China. All cell lines were cultured in RPMI-1640 or Dulbeccoâs modified Eagleâs medium (DMEM, Thermo Scientific) supplemented with 10% fetal calf serum (FCS, Thermo Scientific) and 100 U/mL penicillin and 100 Î¼g/mL streptomycin (Thermo Scientific). All cells were incubated in 12-well plates at a cell density of 1 Ã 105 cells/well at 37 Â°C with 5% CO2. For the cytokine-mediated expression of PD-L1, cells were pretreated with 50 ng/mL IFN-Î³ for 24 h at 37 Â°C with 5% CO2. Cisplatin with a purity of >99.0% was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. PD-1/PD-L1 inhibitor 2 was obtained from Target Molecule (TargetMol).

    Electrophoretic Mobility Shift Assay

    Native polyacrylamide gel (20%) electrophoresis in 1Ã Tris-baseâboric-acidâEDTA (TBE) buffer was used for the EMSA. After the samples were loaded on the gels, the electrophoresis was run at 150 V for 4.5 h at 4 Â°C in circulating cooling water. Then, the gels were removed from the glass plates and immersed in 1Ã SYBR Gold (1:1000 dilution with 1Ã TE buffer) for 30 min and rinsed with ultrapure water. Finally, the gel images were photographed under a Bio-Rad gel imaging analyzer.

    UV Melting Assay

    A UV melting assay was performed on a UV-2550 spectrophotometer (Shimadzu) equipped with quartz cells with a path length of 10 mm and a thermoelectrically controlled cell holder in the presence or absence of newly designed and synthesized polyamides to measure the Tm values of the DNAs according to our previous work.(65,66) The final DNA concentration was 1 Î¼M (double-stranded units) in the sample solution containing 100 mM Tris-HCl buffer containing 50 mM NaCl and 1 mM EDTA. As a reference, the buffer solution without DNA was subjected to the same analysis. The DNA preparations were denatured at 95 Â°C for 10 min, cooled to room temperature, and stored at 4 Â°C overnight. The samples were heated from 20 to 95 Â°C at a rate of 1 Â°C/min, and the absorbance at different ratios was measured.

    Circular Dichroism

    For the CD assay, a Jasco J-815 CD spectropolarimeter equipped with a quartz cuvette with a path length of 5 mm was employed. CD spectra were measured at a scanning rate of 100 nm/min at a bandwidth of 5.0 nm, and the results of three independent experiments were averaged. Means and standard deviations were calculated. A sample of 2 Î¼M ds-DNA or 3 Î¼M ss-DNA was dissolved in buffer (pH 7.4) containing 10 mM sodium cacodylate and 100 mM NaCl and incubated for 24 h after annealing at 95 Â°C for further assays. The polyamides were gradually dropped into target DNA samples at room temperature, which had been degassed before use, at the indicated ratio of compound to DNA (r) in buffer (pH 7.4) containing 10 mM sodium cacodylate, 100 mM NaCl, and 0.5% DMSO. After 15 min to achieve equilibrium, CD spectra from 225 to 400 nm were recorded.

    Surface Plasmon Resonance Assay

    A Biacore X100 system (Sweden) equipped with an SA sensor chip was used to measure the SPR. Tris-based buffer (10 mM TrisâHCl, pH 7.4, containing 10 mM KCl, 0.1 mM EDTA, 0.005% surfactant P20, and 0.5% DMSO (v/v)) was used as the flow solution, and the measurement was conducted at 25 Â°C.(27,28) The processing of data was carried out with BIAevalution software. Flow solution containing sodium chloride (1 M) and sodium hydroxide (50 mM) was used to remove any unbound streptavidin from the surface of the sensor chip. After preconditioning of the sensor chip, its surface was further washed for 10 min to remove any trace of NaOH until the baseline became flat. Next, two annealed DNA oligos, 5â²-biotinâTTCCGCCGATTTCACCGAAGGTCAGGAA-TATA-TTCCTGACCTTCGGTGAAATCGGCGGAA-3â² (5â²-biotinâds-DNA, Table 1) were noncovalently immobilized on an SA sensor chip through a biotinâstreptavidin interaction. After immobilization, the compounds were injected at a flow rate of 20 Î¼L/min, and the equilibrium responses were determined relative to the baseline to obtain experimental data. Finally, the dissociation equilibrium constant (KD, M), the association rate constant (ka, Mâ1 sâ1), the dissociation rate constant (kd, sâ1), and the stoichiometry were calculated by fitting the sensorgram data to a theoretical model, a global 1:1 interaction model with a mass-transfer effect, using the BIAevaluation 4.1 program (Bia-core/GE Healthcare). Then, the affinity and specificity of binding for the polyamide compounds against the 28nt double-stranded PD-L1 DNA (Figure 1B, Table 1) and single-stranded PD-L1 DNA were calculated.

    Molecular Modeling Studies

    Discovery Studio 3.5 (Accelrys, San Diego, CA) software was used for molecular modeling. A double-stranded B-DNA composed of 5â²-TTCACCGAA-3â²/5â²-TTCGGTGAA-3â² was constructed using CHARMM force-field parameters. The starting structure was built based on the structure of the ImPyPy-Î³-PyPyPy-5â²-d(CGCTAACAGGC)-3â²/5â²-d(GCCTGTTAGCG)-3â² complex revealed by NMR.(41) Periodic boundary conditions were used in explicit solvent simulation. The resulting orthorhombic water solvation model contained 0.145 mol/L salt (sodium cation and chloride anion). The minimum distance from the boundary was set to 7 Ã. The entire system was minimized to a root mean square (RMS) of <0.001 kcal/mol Ã without any restrictions.

    Quantitative Real-Time Polymerase Chain Reaction Assay

    To quantify PD-L1 mRNA expression, total RNA was extracted from cells with TRIzol reagent (Invitrogen), and cDNA was synthesized using a first strand cDNA synthesis kit (TOYOBO) according to the manufacturerâs instructions. Quantitative real-time polymerase chain reaction (q-PCR) analysis was performed using the iTaq Universal SYBR Green Supermix (BIO RAD) and an ABI Prism 7900-HT sequence detection system (96-well, BIO RAD). The following primers were used for the amplification of PD-L1: forward primer 5â²-GGACAAGCAGTGACCATCAAG-3â² and reverse primer 5â²-CCCAGAATTACCAAGTGAGTCCT-3â². The following primers were used for the amplification of glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate dehydrogenase (GAPDH): forward primer 5â²-AGAAGGCTGGGGCTCATTTG-3â² and reverse primer 5â²-AGGGGCCATCCACAGTCTTC-3â². The experiments were conducted in triplicate. GAPDH was used as the internal control.

    Western Blot Analysis

    Cells were lysed in 1Ã radioimmunoprecipitation assay (RIPA) buffer with phosphatase inhibitors. Cell lysates were cleared by centrifugation at 4 Â°C for 15 min at 13â¯200g. Protein was separated by sodium dodecyl sulfateâpolyacrylamide gel electrophoresis (SDS-PAGE) and transferred onto a polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) membrane. After being blocked with 5% bovine serum albumin (BSA)/tris-buffered saline, 0.1% TWEEN 20 detergent (TBST) buffer for 2 h, membranes were incubated in primary antibodies overnight at 4 Â°C. The following primary antibodies were used in the dilution, as suggested by the supplier: anti-PD-L1 mAb, anti-Akt mAb, anti-P-Akt mAb, anticaspase-3 mAb (1:1000; Cell Signal Technology), and anti-GAPDH Ab (1:1000; Cell Signal Technology). Then, the membranes were incubated with secondary antibodies for 2 h at room temperature, immersed in BeyoECL Star (Beyotime) for 2 min, and photographed under a Bio-Rad gel imaging analyzer.

    Wound Healing Assay

    MDA-MB-231 and HCC827 cells were cultured at a cell density of 1 Ã 105 cells/mL in DMEM and RPMI1640 medium containing growth factors for 24 h, respectively. An artificial gap was generated using a disposable 200 Î¼L pipet chip on the confluent cell monolayer in a streaking motion. Polyamide compounds at the indicated concentrations were added to the medium of the streaked cell culture. The cells were cultured in serum-free medium for an additional 48 h, and the healing of the gap was photographed. To quantify the effect of the compounds on the wound healing, the % cell inhibitory rate was calculated by the following equation: cell inhibitory rate (%) = (1 â Ddrug/Dcontrol) Ã 100%,(67) in which Ddrug is the mean distance of cell migration in the sample containing drug and Dcontrol is the mean distance of cell migration in the sample without the drug. The images of the initially disturbed monolayers were compared with the corresponding images of cells at the end of the incubation. Data are shown as the mean Â± SD. Artificial lines fitting the cutting edges were drawn on the images of the original artificial gaps and on the images of cultures after incubation. Three different points were marked on each plate. Three independent experiments were done, and the representative images were shown.

    Coculture Experiments and IL-2 Analysis by ELISA

    Jurkat T cells were cocultured with tumor cells, and the production of IL-2 was determined, as previously described.(68) To analyze the effect of compounds on the tumor microenvironment, tumor cells were cocultured with PMA (phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate, Sigma-Aldrich)-activated Jurkat T cells. The cells were cultured at an effector-to-target ratio of 5:1 for 24 or 36 h. IL-2 secreted from Jurkat cells into the medium was determined according to the manufacturerâs protocol (human IL-2 ELISA (enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay) kit, DAKEWE).

    CCK-8 Assay

    The in vitro cytotoxic effect of novel polyamides on HCC827 and MDA-MB-231 and MRC-5 tumor cells was determined by using a Cell Counting Kit-8 assay kit (CCK-8) (Dojindo Molecular Technologies, Kumamoto, Japan) according to the manufacturerâs protocol. In brief, cells were maintained in the complete RPMI 1640 medium (Invitrogen Gibco) at 37 Â°C with 5% CO2. Cells in the logarithmic growth phase were harvested and resuspended in the medium. The cell suspensions (95 Î¼L) were seeded in a 96-well plate, which was incubated for 4 h at 37 Â°C with 5% CO2. Then, 1 Î¼L of a polyamide stock solution in DMSO was diluted with 4 Î¼L of culture medium. After the 5 Î¼L sample was added to the 96-well plate, the plate was cultured for an additional 36 h. Then, 10 Î¼L of CCK-8 reagent was added to each well, and the plate was incubated at 37 Â°C for another 1 h. Finally, the optical density of each sample was measured at 450 nm using a BioTek Synergy H1 microplate reader. Cisplatin was used as a positive control. â1% DMSOâ is a solution containing 1% DMSO in RPMI 1640 as a reference.

    Statistical Analysis

    The Pearson R test, Spearman rank correlation test, and Studentâs t test were performed using GraphPad Prism 6 (GraphPad Software). Data were expressed as the mean Â± standard deviation (S.D.) of three independent experiments, and the difference (P < 0.05) was considered significant.

      Topalian, S. L.; Drake, C. G.; Pardoll, D. M. Immune checkpoint blockade: a common denominator approach to cancer therapy. Cancer Cell 2015, 27, 450â 461, Â DOI: 10.1016/j.ccell.2015.03.001

      2
      Immune Checkpoint Blockade: A Common Denominator Approach to Cancer Therapy
      Topalian, Suzanne L.; Drake, Charles G.; Pardoll, Drew M.
      Cancer Cell (2015), 27 (4), 450-461CODEN: CCAECI; ISSN:1535-6108. (Elsevier Inc.)
      The immune system recognizes and is poised to eliminate cancer but is held in check by inhibitory receptors and ligands. These immune checkpoint pathways, which normally maintain self-tolerance and limit collateral tissue damage during anti-microbial immune responses, can be co-opted by cancer to evade immune destruction. Drugs interrupting immune checkpoints, such as anti-CTLA-4, anti-PD-1, anti-PD-L1, and others in early development, can unleash anti-tumor immunity and mediate durable cancer regressions. The complex biol. of immune checkpoint pathways still contains many mysteries, and the full activity spectrum of checkpoint-blocking drugs, used alone or in combination, is currently the subject of intense study.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXmtVaku7k%253D&md5=e42c02d50881184b78630e5dd23f7f2e
    3. 3
      Ceeraz, S.; Nowak, E. C.; Noelle, R. J. B7 family checkpoint regulators in immune regulation and disease. Trends Immunol. 2013, 34, 556â 563, Â DOI: 10.1016/j.it.2013.07.003
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
      3
      B7 family checkpoint regulators in immune regulation and disease
      Ceeraz, Sabrina; Nowak, Elizabeth C.; Noelle, Randolph J.
      Trends in Immunology (2013), 34 (11), 556-563CODEN: TIRMAE; ISSN:1471-4906. (Elsevier Ltd.)
      A review. Fine-tuning the immune response and maintaining tolerance to self-antigens involves a complex network of co-stimulatory and co-inhibitory mols. The recent FDA approval of ipilimumab, a monoclonal antibody blocking cytotoxic T lymphocyte antigen (CTLA)-4, demonstrates the impact of checkpoint regulators in disease. This is reinforced by ongoing clin. trials targeting not only CTLA-4, but also the programmed death (PD)-1 and B7-H4 pathways in various disease states. Recently, two new B7 family inhibitory ligands, V-domain Ig suppressor of T cell activation (VISTA) and B7-H6 were identified. Here, we review recent understanding of B7 family members and their concerted regulation of the immune response to either self or foreign pathogens. We also discuss clin. developments in targeting these pathways in different disease settings, and introduce VISTA as a putative therapeutic target.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXht1KltbjJ&md5=395a88bdda0a83ec10fe4845d5fa76c9
    4. 4
      Karwacz, K.; Bricogne, C.; MacDonald, D.; Arce, F.; Bennett, C. L.; Collins, M.; Escors, D. PD-L1 co-stimulation contributes to ligand-induced T cell receptor down-modulation on CD8+ T cells. EMBO Mol. Med. 2011, 3, 581â 592, Â DOI: 10.1002/emmm.201100165
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
      4
      PD-L1 co-stimulation contributes to ligand-induced T cell receptor down-modulation on CD8+ T cells
      Karwacz, Katarzyna; Bricogne, Christopher; MacDonald, Douglas; Arce, Frederick; Bennett, Clare L.; Collins, Mary; Escors, David
      EMBO Molecular Medicine (2011), 3 (10), 581-592CODEN: EMMMAM; ISSN:1757-4684. (Wiley-Blackwell)
      T cell receptor (TCR) down-modulation after antigen presentation is a fundamental process that regulates TCR signal transduction. Current understanding of this process is that intrinsic TCR/CD28 signal transduction leads to TCR down-modulation. Here, we show that the interaction between programmed cell death 1 ligand 1 (PD-L1) on dendritic cells (DCs) and programmed death 1 (PD-1) on CD8 T cells contributes to ligand-induced TCR down-modulation. We provide evidence that this occurs via Casitas B-lymphoma (Cbl)-b E3 ubiquitin ligase up-regulation in CD8 T cells. Interference with PD-L1/PD-1 signalling markedly inhibits TCR down-modulation leading to hyper-activated, proliferative CD8 T cells as assessed in vitro and in vivo in an arthritis model. PD-L1 silencing accelerates anti-tumor immune responses and strongly potentiates DC anti-tumor capacities, when combined with mitogen-activated kinase (MAPK) modulators that promote DC activation.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXhtlersL%252FL&md5=4f7eefaa0d962c7118676ed6417d8bc3
    5. 5
      Soria, J. C.; Marabelle, A.; Brahmer, J. R.; Gettinger, S. Immune checkpoint modulation for non-small cell lung cancer. Clin. Cancer Res. 2015, 21, 2256â 2262, Â DOI: 10.1158/1078-0432.CCR-14-2959
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
      5
      Immune Checkpoint Modulation for Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer
      Soria, Jean-Charles; Marabelle, Aurelien; Brahmer, Julie R.; Gettinger, Scott
      Clinical Cancer Research (2015), 21 (10), 2256-2262CODEN: CCREF4; ISSN:1078-0432. (American Association for Cancer Research)
      Therapies targeting immune checkpoints have recently shown encouraging activity in patients with heavily pretreated advanced non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC), independently of NSCLC histol. or mutational status, with low toxicity profiles when used as monotherapy. Objective response rates of approx. 20% have been reported in patients with advanced NSCLC treated with antagonist antibodies targeting the immune checkpoint, programmed death 1 (PD-1) on activated T cells, or its primary ligand, programmed death ligand 1 (PD-L1) expressed within the tumor microenvironment. Response rates appear to be higher in patients with tumor PD-L1 expression documented by immunohistochem., although responses have been appreciated in patients with reportedly PD-L1-neg. tumor specimens. Antibodies directed against cytotoxic T-lymphocyte-assocd. protein 4 (CTLA-4), another immunosuppressive T-cell signaling mol., are also being evaluated in clin. trials, with one randomized phase II trial demonstrating improved immune-related progression-free survival in lung cancer patients when added to std. chemotherapy. Addnl. clin. trials are combining anti-CTLA-4 antibodies with either anti-PD-1 or anti-PD-L1 antibodies. Combinations of other immune checkpoint antagonists or agonist antibodies with anti-PD-1 or anti-PD-L1 antibodies are also being pursued. Clin Cancer Res; 21(10); 2256-62. Â©2015 AACR. See all articles in this section, "Progress in Lung Cancer".
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXoslOktbs%253D&md5=9bb87571496cc02a6172e82023b20f5b
    6. 6
      Clark, C. A.; Gupta, H. B.; Sareddy, G.; Pandeswara, S.; Lao, S.; Yuan, B.; Drerup, J. M.; Padron, A.; Conejo-Garcia, G. J.; Murthy, K.; Liu, Y.; Turk, M. J.; Thedieck, K.; Hurez, V.; Li, R.; Vadlamudi, R.; Curiel, T. J. Tumor intrinsic PD-L1 signals regulate cell growth, pathogenesis, and autophagy in ovarian cancer and melanoma. Cancer Res. 2016, 76, 6964â 6974, Â DOI: 10.1158/0008-5472.CAN-16-0258
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
      6
      Tumor-Intrinsic PD-L1 Signals Regulate Cell Growth, Pathogenesis, and Autophagy in Ovarian Cancer and Melanoma
      Clark, Curtis A.; Gupta, Harshita B.; Sareddy, Gangadhara; Pandeswara, Srilakshmi; Lao, Shunhua; Yuan, Bin; Drerup, Justin M.; Padron, Alvaro; Conejo-Garcia, Jose; Murthy, Kruthi; Liu, Yang; Turk, Mary Jo; Thedieck, Kathrin; Hurez, Vincent; Li, Rong; Vadlamudi, Ratna; Curiel, Tyler J.
      Cancer Research (2016), 76 (23), 6964-6974CODEN: CNREA8; ISSN:0008-5472. (American Association for Cancer Research)
      PD-L1 antibodies produce efficacious clin. responses in diverse human cancers, but the basis for their effects remains unclear, leaving a gap in the understanding of how to rationally leverage therapeutic activity. PD-L1 is widely expressed in tumor cells, but its contributions to tumor pathogenicity are incompletely understood. In this study, we evaluated the hypothesis that PD-L1 exerts tumor cell-intrinsic signals that are crit. for pathogenesis. Using RNAi methodol., we attenuated PD-L1 in the murine ovarian cell line ID8agg and the melanoma cell line B16 (termed PD-L1lo cells), which express basal PD-L1. We obsd. that PD-L1lo cells proliferated more weakly than control cells in vitro. As expected, PD-L1lo cells formed tumors in immunocompetent mice relatively more slowly, but unexpectedly, they also formed tumors more slowly in immunodeficient NSG mice. RNA sequencing anal. identified a no. of genes involved in autophagy and mTOR signaling that were affected by PD-L1 expression. In support of a functional role, PD-L1 attenuation augmented autophagy and blunted the ability of autophagy inhibitors to limit proliferation in vitro and in vivo in NSG mice. PD-L1 attenuation also reduced mTORC1 activity and augmented the antiproliferative effects of the mTORC1 inhibitor rapamycin. PD-L1lo cells were also relatively deficient in metastasis to the lung, and we found that anti-PD-L1 administration could block tumor cell growth and metastasis in NSG mice. This therapeutic effect was obsd. with B16 cells but not ID8agg cells, illustrating tumor- or compartmental-specific effects in the therapeutic setting. Overall, our findings extend understanding of PD-L1 functions, illustrate nonimmune effects of anti-PD-L1 immunotherapy, and suggest broader uses for PD-L1 as a biomarker for assessing cancer therapeutic responses. Cancer Res; 76(23); 6964-74. Â©2016 AACR.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XhvFyntrjP&md5=02dafdbfde9636f0272c53255c4e2d3c
    7. 7
      Chang, C.; Qiu, J.; OâSullivan, D.; Buck, M. D.; Noguchi, T.; Curtis, J. D.; Chen, Q.; Gindin, M.; Gubin, M. M.; van der Windt, G. J. W.; Tonc, E.; Schreiber, R. D.; Pearce, E. J.; Pearce, E. L. Metabolic competition in the tumor microenvironment is a driver of cancer progression. Cell 2015, 162, 1229â 1241, Â DOI: 10.1016/j.cell.2015.08.016
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
      7
      Metabolic Competition in the Tumor Microenvironment Is a Driver of Cancer Progression
      Chang, Chih-Hao; Qiu, Jing; O'Sullivan, David; Buck, Michael D.; Noguchi, Takuro; Curtis, Jonathan D.; Chen, Qiongyu; Gindin, Mariel; Gubin, Matthew M.; van der Windt, Gerritje J. W.; Tonc, Elena; Schreiber, Robert D.; Pearce, Edward J.; Pearce, Erika L.
      Cell (Cambridge, MA, United States) (2015), 162 (6), 1229-1241CODEN: CELLB5; ISSN:0092-8674. (Cell Press)
      Failure of T cells to protect against cancer is thought to result from lack of antigen recognition, chronic activation, and/or suppression by other cells. Using a mouse sarcoma model, we show that glucose consumption by tumors metabolically restricts T cells, leading to their dampened mTOR activity, glycolytic capacity, and IFN-Î³ prodn., thereby allowing tumor progression. We show that enhancing glycolysis in an antigenic "regressor" tumor is sufficient to override the protective ability of T cells to control tumor growth. We also show that checkpoint blockade antibodies against CTLA-4, PD-1, and PD-L1, which are used clin., restore glucose in tumor microenvironment, permitting T cell glycolysis and IFN-Î³ prodn. Furthermore, we found that blocking PD-L1 directly on tumors dampens glycolysis by inhibiting mTOR activity and decreasing expression of glycolysis enzymes, reflecting a role for PD-L1 in tumor glucose utilization. Our results establish that tumor-imposed metabolic restrictions can mediate T cell hyporesponsiveness during cancer.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhsVajs7%252FI&md5=cfc0a1c9d46d34259927a0130bd380a7
    8. 8
      Bromberg, J. F.; Wrzeszczynska, M. H.; Devgan, G.; Zhao, Y.; Pestell, R. G.; Albanese, C.; Darnell, J. E., Jr. STAT3 as an oneogene. Cell 1999, 98, 295â 303, Â DOI: 10.1016/S0092-8674(00)81959-5

      8
      Stat3 as an oncogene
      Bromberg, Jacqueline F.; Wrzeszczynska, Melissa H.; Devgan, Geeta; Zhao, Yanxiang; Pestell, Richard G.; Albanese, Chris; Darnell, James E., Jr.
      Cell (Cambridge, Massachusetts) (1999), 98 (3), 295-303CODEN: CELLB5; ISSN:0092-8674. (Cell Press)
      STATs are latent transcription factors that mediate cytokine- and growth factor-directed transcription. In many human cancers and transformed cell lines, Stat3 is persistently activated, and in cell culture, active Stat3 is either required for transformation, enhances transformation, or blocks apoptosis. Here, the substitution of two cysteine residues within the C-terminal loop of the SH2 domain of Stat3 produced a mol. that dimerizes spontaneously, binds to DNA, and activates transcription. The Stat3-C mol. in immortalized fibroblasts causes cellular transformation scored by colony formation in soft agar and tumor formation in nude mice. Thus, the activated Stat3 mol. by itself can mediate cellular transformation and the expts. focus attention on the importance of constitutive Stat3 activation in human tumors.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK1MXlt1Cgt7s%253D&md5=f2e69e246bbfae15a3c5ee7b94340300
    9. 9
      Decker, T.; Kovarik, P. Serine phosphorylation of STATs. Oncogene 2000, 19, 2628â 2637, Â DOI: 10.1038/sj.onc.1203481
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
      9
      Serine phosphorylation of STATs
      Decker, Thomas; Kovarik, Pavel
      Oncogene (2000), 19 (21), 2628-2637CODEN: ONCNES; ISSN:0950-9232. (Nature Publishing Group)
      A review with 74 refs. Tyrosine phosphorylation regulates the dimerization of STATs as an essential prerequisite for the establishment of a classical JAK-STAT signaling path. However, most vertebrate STATs contain a second phosphorylation site within their C-termini. The phosphorylated residue in this case is a serine contained within a P(M)SP motif, and in the majority of situations its mutation to alanine alters transcription factor activity. This review addresses recent advances in understanding the regulation of STAT serine phosphorylation, as well as the kinases and other signal transducers implied in this process. The biochem. and biol. consequences of STAT serine phosphorylation are discussed.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®

      Yu, H.; Jove, R. The STATs of cancer-new molecular targets come of age. Nat. Rev. Cancer 2004, 4, 97â 105, Â DOI: 10.1038/nrc1275
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
      10
      The STATs of cancer - new molecular targets come of age
      Yu, Hua; Jove, Richard
      Nature Reviews Cancer (2004), 4 (2), 97-105CODEN: NRCAC4; ISSN:1474-175X. (Nature Publishing Group)
      A review. Tumor cells acquire the ability to proliferate uncontrollably, resist apoptosis, sustain angiogenesis and evade immune surveillance. STAT proteins - esp. STAT3 and STAT5 - regulate all of these processes and are persistently activated in a surprisingly large no. of human cancers. Consequently, STAT proteins are emerging - unexpectedly - as ideal targets for cancer therapy.

      11
      Somatic STAT3 mutations in large granular lymphocytic leukemia
      Koskela, Hanna L. M.; Eldfors, Samuli; Ellonen, Pekka; van Adrichem, Arjan J.; Kuusanmaki, Heikki; Andersson, Emma I.; Lagstrom, Sonja; Clemente, Michael J.; Olson, Thomas; Jalkanen, Sari E.; Majumder, Muntasir Mamun; Almusa, Henrikki; Edgren, Henrik; Lepisto, Maija; Mattila, Pirkko; Guinta, Kathryn; Koistinen, Pirjo; Kuittinen, Taru; Penttinen, Kati; Parsons, Alun; Knowles, Jonathan; Saarela, Janna; Wennerberg, Krister; Kallioniemi, Olli; Porkka, Kimmo; Loughran, Thomas P., Jr.; Heckman, Caroline A.; Maciejewski, Jaroslaw P.; Mustjoki, Satu
      New England Journal of Medicine (2012), 366 (20), 1905-1913CODEN: NEJMAG; ISSN:0028-4793. (Massachusetts Medical Society)
      T-cell large granular lymphocytic leukemia is a rare lymphoproliferative disorder characterized by the expansion of clonal CD3+CD8+ cytotoxic T lymphocytes (CTLs) and often assocd. with autoimmune disorders and immune-mediated cytopenias. We used next-generation exome sequencing to identify somatic mutations in CTLs from an index patient with large granular lymphocytic leukemia. Targeted resequencing was performed in a well-characterized cohort of 76 patients with this disorder, characterized by clonal T-cell-receptor rearrangements and increased nos. of large granular lymphocytes. Mutations in the signal transducer and activator of transcription 3 gene (STAT3) were found in 31 of 77 patients (40%) with large granular lymphocytic leukemia. Among these 31 patients, recurrent mutational hot spots included Y640F in 13 (17%), D661V in 7 (9%), D661Y in 7 (9%), and N647I in 3 (4%). All mutations were located in exon 21, encoding the Src homol. 2 (SH2) domain, which mediates the dimerization and activation of STAT protein. The amino acid changes resulted in a more hydrophobic protein surface and were assocd. with phosphorylation of STAT3 and its localization in the nucleus. In vitro functional studies showed that the Y640F and D661V mutations increased the transcriptional activity of STAT3. In the affected patients, downstream target genes of the STAT3 pathway (IFNGR2, BCL2L1, and JAK2) were up-regulated. Patients with STAT3 mutations presented more often with neutropenia and rheumatoid arthritis than did patients without these mutations. The SH2 dimerization and activation domain of STAT3 is frequently mutated in patients with large granular lymphocytic leukemia; these findings suggest that aberrant STAT3 signaling underlies the pathogenesis of this disease.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38Xntlalsr8%253D&md5=4282683e8c70804aaac1818ea4e278d3
    12. 12
      WÃ¶lfle, S. J.; Strebovsky, J.; Bartz, H.; SÃ¤hr, A.; Arnold, C.; Kaiser, C.; Dalpke, A. H.; Heeg, K. PD-L1 expression on tolerogenic APCs is controlled by STAT-3. Eur. J. Immunol. 2011, 41, 413â 424, Â DOI: 10.1002/eji.201040979
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
      12
      PD-L1 expression on tolerogenic APCs is controlled by STAT-3
      Wolfle Sabine J; Strebovsky Julia; Bartz Holger; Sahr Aline; Arnold Caroline; Kaiser Claus; Dalpke Alexander H; Heeg Klaus
      European journal of immunology (2011), 41 (2), 413-24 ISSN:.
      During infection, TLR agonists are released and trigger mature as well as differentiating innate immune cells. Early encounter with TLR agonists (R848; LPS) blocks conventional differentiation of CD14(+) monocytes into immature dendritic cells (iDCs) resulting in a deviated phenotype. We and others characterized these APCs (TLR-APC) by a retained expression of CD14 and a lack of CD1a. Here, we show in addition, expression of programmed death ligand-1 (PD-L1). TLR-APCs failed to induce T-cell proliferation and furthermore were able to induce CD25(+) Foxp3(+) T regulatory cells (Tregs). Since PD-L1 is described as a key negative regulator and inducer of tolerance, we further analyzed its regulation. PD-L1 expression was regulated in a MAPK/cytokine/STAT-3-dependent manner: high levels of IL-6 and IL-10 that signal via STAT-3 were produced by TLR-APCs. Blocking of STAT-3 activation prevented PD-L1 expression. Moreover, chromatin immunoprecipitation revealed direct binding of STAT-3 to the PD-L1 promoter. Those findings indicate a pivotal role of STAT-3 in regulating PD-L1 expression. MAPKs were indirectly engaged, as blocking of p38 and p44/42 MAPKs decreased IL-6 and IL-10 thus reducing STAT-3 activation and subsequent PD-L1 expression. Hence, during DC differentiation TLR agonists induce a STAT-3-mediated expression of PD-L1 and favor the development of tolerogenic APCs.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BC3M7ksVKrtQ%253D%253D&md5=cb53ad4a94a23a6c12269ff67b5d0cb3
